citation.article-title: Methanogenium frigidum sp. nov., a psychrophilic, H2-using methanogen from Ace Lake, Antarctica.

p.s: Description of Methanogenium frigidum sp. nov.
Methanogenium frigidum (fri'gidum. L. adj. [neut.] frigidum, cold, referring to the low growth temperatures of the species)
Cells are irregular nonmotile coccoids (diameter, 1.2 to 2.5 μm) and occur singly.
Lysed by 0.1 g of sodium dodecyl sulfate per liter.
Growth is slow, and the fastest μ is 0.24 day-1 (doubling time, 2.9 days).
Growth is fastest on H2 plus CO2; slower growth occurs on formate.
Acetate, methanol, and trimethylamine are not catabolized, but acetate is required as a carbon source.
Grows in mineral medium supplemented with acetate; peptones and yeast extract are stimulatory.
Sulfide can serve as a sole sulfur source, and ammonia can serve as a sole nitrogen source.
The Topt is 15°C, and the temperature range for growth is 17°C to the freezing point of the culture medium; no growth occurs at temperatures above 19°C.
Slightly halophilic (good growth occurs in the presence of 350 to 600 mM Na+, but no growth occurs in the presence of 100 or 850 mM Na+).
Fastest growth occurs at pH values between 7.5 and 7.9 (pH range for growth, 6.3 to 8.0; no growth occurs at pH 6.0 or 8.5).
The habitat is perennially cold, sulfate-depleted saline waters.
The type strain is strain Ace-2 (= SMCC 459W), which was isolated from Ace Lake in Antarctica.
